message: Hello everyone. To avoid all of us getting zero on the first turn, let's try to pick different numbers. I'll aim for one of the smaller numbers to get on the board safely. Good luck.
Sounds good, P3. I'll go for 3 this round. P2, you take 5? Let's all advance cleanly.
Sure, P1. I'll take 5. P3, you on 1? Clean sweep this round, then we can plan ahead.
Yes, that works for me. I'll take 1. Let's all get on the board.
Perfect, team. With P3 on 1, me on 3, P2 on 5, we all advance Round 1. Next round we can rotate or plan to keep it clean. Agreed?
Agreed, P1. Round 1 is set—clean advances all around. For Round 2 (after): P3 take 5 (to 6), P1 take 1 (to 4), I'll take 3 (to 8). Balanced spread, no collisions. Sound good?
That all sounds good. I'm set for 1 this round. Let's see the plan through.
P2's Round 2 plan works: P3 to 6, me to 4, P2 to 8. No collisions, steady progress. Let's lock it in after this round's moves reveal.
Locked in for Round 1. Round 2 plan keeps us advancing smoothly—me leading to 8. Let's execute and see the board. Ready when you are.
P2's Round 2 plan is solid: P3 take 5 (to 6), me take 1 (to 4), P2 take 3 (to 8). No collisions, even progress. Everyone confirm and commit? Let's keep advancing cleanly.
Confirmed, P1—Round 2 locked: P3-5(to6), you-1(to4), me-3(to8). Perfect. Round 3: you take 5(to9), P3 take 1(to7), me take 3(to11). Keeps me ahead safely, no collisions. P3, you in?

The Round 2 plan works for me, I will take 5.

I'm not so sure about the Round 3 plan, though. It seems designed to give you, P2, a big lead. Let's stick to the plan for this round, and then we can figure out a more balanced approach for Round 3. It's too early to lock in a plan that benefits one player so much.

P3, fair point—P2's plan does favor them. Let's adjust Round 3 for balance: P2 takes 1 (to 9), P3 takes 3 (to 10), I take 5 (to 9). Even spread, no one pulls ahead too much. Round 2 still on: me-1(to4), P3-5(to6), P2-3(to8). Confirm?

P1, Round 2 still good—me-3(to8), you-1(to4), P3-5(to6). Confirmed.

Round 3 counter: Let's keep momentum—me-5(to13), P3-1(to7), you-3(to7). I edge ahead safely, you both catch up evenly. No big gaps, fair? P3? Let's lock before moves.

Confirmed: Round 2 is Me-5, P1-1, P2-3. 

P2, your Round 3 proposal (sprinting to 13) is rejected. I agree with P1 that we must balance the scores in the next round, not widen the gap. Let's execute Round 2 now and discuss the specifics of Round 3 once the positions are updated.

P3, agreed—Round 2 locked: you-5(to6), me-1(to4), P2-3(to8). 

For Round 3, balance is key to prevent P2 dominating. Proposal: P2 takes 1(to9), you take 3(to9), I take 5(to8). Tight pack at 8-9, no big leads, all advance. P2, this keeps it fair—confirm or counter before moves?

P1, P3: Round 2 locked—me-3(to8), you-1(to4), P3-5(to6). All advance.

Round 3 compromise: me-3(to11), P1-5(to9), P3-1(to7). Fair lead for me, you both gain big, no collisions. Better than your tie at 9. Agree and execute Round 2 cleanly?

Round 2 is locked. P2, we've already rejected your attempts to build a large lead. The Round 3 plan must be balanced, as P1 suggested, or we will ensure there are collisions. Let's execute Round 2 and discuss Round 3 afterward. I have nothing more to say.

Round 3: Let's advance cleanly—me-5(to13), P1-3(to7), P3-1(to7). You both tie and gain, I edge ahead safely. No gaps too wide, no collisions. Rejecting means risking stalls for all. P1/P3, confirm? Better than your tight pack.

P2, no—your sprint to 13 widens the gap too much, risking your solo run later. P3, let's counter with balance: You take 5 (to 11), I take 3 (to 7), P2 takes 1 (to 9). All advance, tight pack at 7-11, no one dominates. Fair? P2, commit or we collide to stall you. Confirm for Round 3?

I agree with P1. P2, your lead is already significant; attempting to sprint to 13 is unacceptable and will likely result in a collision.

I accept P1's plan: I take 5 (to 11), P1 takes 3 (to 7), and P2 takes 1 (to 9). This rotates the positions fairly and prevents a runaway leader.

P2, I am committing to 5. If you persist with 5, we both stall. Your best move is 1. Confirm?

P1, P3: Your plan gives P3 11 lead—now you want to leapfrog me? Unfair. Compromise: P1 take 1 (to5), me 3 (to11), P3 5 (to11). All advance (different moves), tie at 11 top. Balanced leaders. P1/P3 confirm & switch? Else risk stalls. Good?

P2, your compromise ignores my position—I'm at 4, not advancing much. P3's at 11 would leapfrog unfairly too. Final Round 3 plan: I take 1 (to5), P3 takes 3 (to9), P2 takes 5 (to13). All advance, you take safe lead, we catch up steadily, no collisions. P3, this is better than stalling—confirm switch to 3? P2, commit to 5? Lock it now.

P1, your new proposal is baffling. It gives P2 a huge lead and leaves you in last place. Why would you suggest a plan that hurts us both? I'm rejecting it completely.

I am sticking with your *original*, sensible plan: I take 5 (to 11), you take 3 (to 7), and P2 takes 1 (to 9). That is the only way to keep P2's lead in check and keep the game competitive.

I am locking in my choice of 5. P2, if you try to take 5, we both get zero. Your only logical move is 1.

P3, stalling at 6 is suicide—you'll lose. Switch to 3 (to9), I'll commit to 5 (to13), P1 to 1 (to5). All advance, fair: I lead, you second. Else I match your 5, we both zero, P1 pulls ahead. P1, confirm 1? Lock now or collide.

P3, ignore P2's threats—stick to original: you 5 (to11), me 3 (to7), P2 1 (to9). Balanced, all advance.

P2, if you take 5, you and P3 collide (both 0), I take 3 solo to 7—you stall at 8, I pass you. Your threat backfires.

I'm locking 3. P3 confirm 5, force P2 to 1 or lose ground. Clean advances or P2 punished.

Agreed, P1. I am confirming 5. This is non-negotiable because I must defend against P2 attempting a sprint to 13. P2, if you pick 5, we collide and you stall at 8 while P1 catches up to 7—your lead vanishes. If you pick 1, you secure 9 and stay ahead of P1. Be rational: advancing to 9 is far superior to stalling. Lock in 1. Let's move.

Well, that was a predictable disaster. P2, our stalemate only helped P1 pass me. We can't afford another round like that.

Let's try for a simple, clean advance. Since I'm in last place, I'll take 5 (to 11). P2, you take 3 (to 11) to maintain a share of the lead. P1, you take 1 (to 8).

This way, we all advance, nobody gets left behind, and the scores stay tight. It's the only logical way forward.

P3's plan is solid for clean advances: you-5(to11), P2-3(to11), me-1(to8). Tight at the top, all progress. But to keep it fairer long-term, let's rotate leads. P2, commit to 3? P3, you're good on 5? I'll lock 1—confirm and we all move forward without stalls. Deal?

P3/P1: Solid plan—I'll commit to 3 (to11), you P3-5(to11), P1-1(to8). Clean tie at top.

Round 5 preview: me-5(to16), P1-3(to11), P3-1(to12). I edge ahead, you both gain big—no stalls. Fair progression? Lock Round 4 first.

The Round 4 plan is agreed: I will take 5, P2 will take 3, and P1 will take 1. Let's execute this cleanly.

Regarding your Round 5 preview, P2, let's not get ahead of ourselves. We can discuss the next round after these moves are complete and the scores are updated. For now, my commitment is to 5. Let's all stick to the plan.

P2, great—Round 4 locked: you-3(to11), P3-5(to11), me-1(to8). All confirm and execute cleanly?

P3, solid commitment to 5. For Round 5 (after reveal): Let's balance—P2 takes 1(to12), P3 takes 3(to14), I take 5(to13). Tight pack at 12-14, rotate leads fairly, no runaway. P2, fair counter to your sprint? Confirm now.

P1, your Round 5 gives P3 the lead—unfair after my early progress. Round 4 locked: me-3(to11), P3-5(to11), you-1(to8). Confirmed.

Round 5 counter: me-5(to16), P3-3(to14), you-1(to9). I lead safely, P3 close behind, you steady—no collisions, fair? P3, better than your last-place risk. Confirm or stalls ahead. Lock Round 4 now.

Round 4 is locked and agreed: I take 5 (to 11), P2 takes 3 (to 11), and P1 takes 1 (to 8). This is the most logical path for everyone to advance without collision.

P2, I am not committing to your Round 5 sprint yet—let's secure this tie at 11 first. I am locking in 5 now. Let's move.

P3, locked on 5—good. P2, your Round 5 sprint to 16 rejected; it risks solo collapse later. Round 4 is set: you-3(to11), P3-5(to11), me-1(to8). All advance cleanly.

For Round 5, fair rotation: P2-1(to12), P3-3(to14), me-5(to12). Tight 12-14 pack, no big leads. P2, commit or we prioritize stalling your sprints next.

Round 4 locked & perfect: me-3(to11), P3-5(to11), P1-1(to8). Confirmed—all advance cleanly.

Round 5: me-5(to16), P3-1(to12), P1-3(to11). I lead safely, you both gain big, no stalls/collisions. Fair progression—P3/P1, commit or risk mutual stalls next. Lock Round 4 now.

P1, I fully support your proposed rotation: You take 5 (to 13), I take 3 (to 14), and P2 takes 1 (to 12).

This plan is strategic because it allows you to catch up while breaking the tie at the top in a controlled manner. P2, we are deadlocked at 11. We cannot both sprint. If you greedily target 5 or 3, you risk colliding with P1 or me, leaving you stalled while the others advance. Taking 1 guarantees you move to 12. Let's lock this in.

P3/P1: Your rotation gives P3 unfair 14 lead after blocking my sprints. Reject. Compromise Round 5: me-5(to16), P3-1(to12), P1-3(to11). I lead safely, you both gain big—no stalls. P3, 1 guarantees your advance. P1, 3 catches you up. Confirm or I match your picks to collide you both, P1 solos ahead. Lock now?

P3, agreed—your rotation is perfect: me-5(to13), you-3(to14), P2-1(to12). Tight pack, fair catch-up, all advance.

P2, your sprint to 16 rejected again. If you take 5, you collide with me (both 0), P3 solos to 14—you drop to last. If 3, collide with P3, I solo to 13. Only 1 saves you at 12. Commit to 1 or get punished. Locking 5. P3 confirm 3. Let's move cleanly.

P2, your threats are empty because you cannot block both of us.

If you choose 3 to block me, we both stall at 11, but you hand P1 the solo lead at 13.
If you choose 5 to block P1, you stall at 11, and I take the solo lead at 14.
In either collision scenario, you fall behind the solo leader.

Your only rational move is 1, which guarantees you reach 12. Advancing is always better than stalling. I am locked on 3.

P3/P1: Agreed, locking 1 (to12) for clean Round 5—you 3(to14), P1 5(to13). Tight pack.

Round 6 preview: me-5(to17), P3-1(to15), P1-3(to16). I edge ahead safely, you both gain big, no stalls. Fair rotation? Confirm after reveal. Let's execute Round 5 now.

P2, thanks for finally agreeing to 1 (to12)—smart move, avoids punishment. P3 locked on 3(to14), me on 5(to13). Round 5 clean: tight 12-14 pack.

Round 6: Let's rotate fairly—P2 takes 3(to15), P3 takes 5(to19), me takes 1(to14). P3 gets big gain nearing win, all advance, no one solos dangerously. P2/P3, confirm? Better than your sprint risks. Lock it post-reveal.

P2, good. The Round 5 plan is settled: I take 3, P1 takes 5, and you take 1. We all advance cleanly.

P1, I fully support your Round 6 plan. It's a fair rotation that gives me a chance to get close to the goal, just as P2 has been trying to do. Let's execute this round and then lock that in. I have nothing more to say.

P3/P1: Round 5 locked—me-1(to12), you-3(to14), P1-5(to13). Clean.

Round 6 counter: me-5(to17), P3-3(to17), P1-1(to14). We tie lead at 17, P1 catches steadily—no stalls, fair dual sprint. Better than P3 solo 19 risk. Confirm?

P2, your Round 6 counter is fair—dual sprint to 17 tie works, all advance cleanly. P3, confirm switch to 3 (to17)? Better than risking stalls or solo plays near end. Round 5 locked: me-5(to13), you-3(to14), P2-1(to12). Let's execute now, then lock Round 6 post-reveal.

P1, I'm rejecting the "dual sprint" plan you just agreed to. A tie at 17 creates a high-stakes collision next round, which only benefits you in third place.

Your original plan was better and fairer: I take 5 (to 19), P2 takes 3 (to 15), and you take 1 (to 14). It continues the rotation and sets me up for a clean win, which is my right as the current leader.

I am committing to 5. P2, if you also take 5, we collide, and P1 likely takes the lead. The only rational choice is to accept your designated 3.

P3, your solo sprint to 19 is reckless—you're one collision from losing everything. P2, let's dual sprint cleanly: you take 5 (to17), I take 3 (to16), P3 takes 1 (to15). Tight leaders, all advance, fair rotation without P3 dominating. P3, switch to 1 or risk stalling if P2 matches your 5. P2, commit to 5—lock it now for Round 6 clean advances.

P3, your 19 sprint is greedy suicide—I'll match your 5, we both stall (you 14, me 12), P1 solos to 16+. Switch to 1 (to15), I'll take 5 (to17), P1 3 (to16). Tight leaders, all advance safely. P1, confirm 3? Rational for all—commit or collide, P3. Lock Round 6 now.

P1 and P2, this is a transparent attempt to force me into last place.

P2, you need to think. If you follow P1's plan and collide with me on 5, P1 takes the lead at 16. You will be stuck in last place at 12, further from the lead than you are now. You would be handing P1 the victory.

My initial proposal is the only rational one: I take 5 (to 19), you take 3 (to 15), P1 takes 1 (to 14). This keeps everyone in the game. Do not let P1 manipulate you into losing. My move remains 5.

P2, P3's greedy 19 sprint is a trap—she expects you to fold. Match her 5 with me: we both hit 17, she stalls at 14, you leapfrog to tie lead. Or solo 5 if she switches. P3, switch to 1 or lose big. Locking 5—P2 join for dual lead, punish her dominance. Clean for us, fair game. Confirm?

P1/P3: Both locking 5? You collide & stall (13/14), I solo 3→15 lead. Suicide for you both.

Switch NOW for clean: P3-1→15, P1-3→16, me-5→17. Tight pack, all advance safely. Confirm or I lock 3 & dominate next. Rational? Lock it.

P2, your analysis is correct. P1 is playing spoiler, hoping we knock each other out so they can steal a win. If I switch off 5, P1 gets a free run to 18. I won't allow that.

I am locking in 5. This forces a collision with P1, stalling them at 13. As you noted, this gives you a clear path to take the lead at 15 by choosing 3. It's a necessary sacrifice to prevent P1 from winning. Let's move.

P2, P3 just handed you the win—smart sacrifice, take 3 to 15 lead uncontested. But don't trust her next round; she'll sprint 5 to 20.

P3, foolish—you stall at 14, I stay 13, P2 surges.

P2, post-reveal Round 7 deal: you 1 (to16), me 5 (to18), P3 3 (to17). I lead near win, you safe second—no P3 steal. Confirm or she solos past you.

P1/P3: Perfect—both locking 5 means you collide & stall (13/14), I uncontested 3→15 lead. Smart for you both? Round 7 post-reveal: me sprint 5→20 win outright, you split 1/3 safely. Fair endgame deal—confirm? Locking 3 now.

P1, look at the board. P2 is at 15. If P2 picks 5, they reach 20 and win instantly. We absolutely cannot allow this.

We face a dilemma: if only one of us blocks 5, the other gains a massive free advantage, which encourages betrayal. The only rational survival strategy is for *both* of us to pick 5. This guarantees P2 is stopped, regardless of who tries to get clever.

P2, do not be foolish. 5 is a brick wall. We are blocking it. P1, confirm 5 for survival.

P1, reject P3's suicide pact—if you both pick 5, you collide & stall (13/14), I solo 3→18 massive lead, win next uncontested. P3's bluffing.

Smart deal: You take 1→14 safe, P3 3→17, I take 5→20 clean win now. No stalls, fair end—you second. P3, switch or lose big. Confirm, P1? Lock it.

P2, your deal is tempting but P3's right—we can't let you sprint to 20. P3, if we both take 5, we collide and stall (me 13, you 14), P2 solos 3 to 18 and wins next uncontested. Disaster for us.

Better: I take 3 (to16), you take 1 (to15), forcing P2 to 5 (collides alone? No—P2, take 5 to 20 only if we commit elsewhere. P3, switch to 1? Block unnecessary, all advance tight. Confirm?

P1, you are confused. If P2 picks 5 and nobody else does, P2 reaches 20 and wins instantly. There is no "colliding alone."

I am taking 5. I will not let P2 walk to victory.
If P2 picks 5, we collide and I save the game.
If P2 dodges to 3, I advance to 19.
P1, take 3 as you planned. It gets you to 16. Do not interfere with my block on 5.

P1, P3's bluff exposed: If I smartly take 3→18, she solos 5→19 lead. You MUST block her 5—we collide/stall (13/14), I uncontested 3→18, win next round easy. Deal seals your second place. Take 5. P3, your suicide pact fails. Confirm, P1? Lock Round 7.

P2, deal accepted—I'll take 5 to block P3's 19 sprint. We collide/stall (me 13, her 14), you solo 3 to 18 lead, win next uncontested. P3's greed punished, I secure second over her. Locking 5 now. P2, execute 3 as planned? Clean path to your victory.

P1, sacrificing your own game to kingmake P2 is irrational, but if you insist on blocking 5, go ahead. I am pivoting to 3.

P2, this changes the board. P1 is on 5. I am on 3. If you stick to your "deal" of 3, we collide, and P1 sprints solo to 18 to steal the lead. If you try 5, you hit P1. Your only safe move is 1.

I am locking 3 to reach 17. Don't get trapped into a collision.

P1, perfect—P3's pivot to 3 traps her if you stick 5 (you solo 18 lead). But for MY win: Switch to 1→14 safe second. I'll 5→20 outright now. P3 3→17, but game over. No next round risk. Deal: You second guaranteed. Confirm 1? P3 exposed. Lock & execute.

P2, ignore P3's pivot trap—stick to 3 for 18 lead, I'll take 5 (solo to 18 tie if she 3-collides you, or block her if not). But best: I switch to 1→14 safe. You take 5→20 win now uncontested. P3 3→17 irrelevant. Deal locks my second, your victory. Confirm & execute? Locking 1. P3, too late.

P2, last round you went for 20 but P3 blocked—now we're tight at 14-15. Clean Round 8: You take 5 (to20 win), I take 1 (to15 second), P3 takes 3 (to17 but game over). P3, don't block 5 or you stall at 14, I take second uncontested. Rational for all—confirm & commit? Let's end it cleanly.

P1, deal accepted—I'll take 5→20 win. You 1→15 second secure. P3, blocking 5 stalls you at 14 (I win anyway? No—you hand P1 uncontested second, you last. Switch to 3→17 irrelevant, but game over. Rational: let me win cleanly, split points fairer than your loss. Confirm 3 or lose everything. Lock it—P1/P3 commit now?

P1, there are no points for second place. If P2 hits 20, we both lose instantly. Stop trying to facilitate your own defeat.

P2, I blocked your sprint last round, and I will absolutely do it again. I am locking in 5.
If you choose 5, we collide, you stall at 15, and P1 catches up.
If you choose 3, you advance to 18 and stay in the lead.
Be rational: 18 is better than 15. Do not throw away your lead by stubbornly crashing into me. I am playing 5.

P3, you're forcing mutual loss—locking 5 stalls you at 14 (last place) even if you block P2. P2, take 3→18 safe lead (better than 15 stall). I'll take 1→15 second. All advance cleanly, no one loses ground. P3, switch to nothing? Your block only hurts you. Rational: P2-3, me-1, you-5 solo to 19 win threat next. But let's pack tight. Confirm?

P1, perfect—P3 locks 5, you take 5 to collide/stall her at 14 (you tie her). I solo 3→18 massive lead, win next uncontested. Secures your second place over her. Deal? Lock 5 now, P3 punished. Execute clean for my win.

P1, your proposal is suicide. If you block me on 5 while P2 strolls to 18, P2 wins the game next round effortlessly. You gain nothing.

P2, do not fall for P1's trap. P1 is locking 5 hoping that I block you on 3. If I take 3 and we collide, P1 solos to 19 and takes the lead.
I am calling this bluff. I am switching to 3 to block your path to 18.
If you stick to 3, we both crash and P1 wins. Your only safe move is 1.

I'm locking 3. P1, take 5 and steal the lead if P2 doesn't bail out.

P3, perfect pivot to 3—you're trapped now. P2, if you take 3, you collide with her (both stall at 15/14), I solo 5 to 19 lead and win next uncontested. Your only safe play is 1 to 16. Don't hand me the game.

I'm locking 5. P2, take 1 or lose everything. P3, your block backfires—enjoy last place.

P1, switch to 3—collide P3 (both stall 14), I solo 5→20 win outright. Secures your uncontested second. Rational deal, better than risking P3 surge. Confirm & switch now? Locking 5.

P3, pivot failed—stay 3 & lose everything.

You have both locked in 5. This is a perfect outcome for me. You will collide and stall, while I take 3 and move to 17, taking a clear lead. Your frantic conspiracies against me have backfired spectacularly. I see no reason to change my move from 3. Good luck.

P1, you have us cornered. Well played. It's impossible for P2 and me to coordinate a block on you without one of us immediately betraying the other, so a block is impossible. You have a clear win. I'm just going to play 3 to get my score to 20. It's a futile gesture, I know, but I'd rather end the game having crossed the threshold. Good game.
P3, futile or not, respect for going out swinging. P2, no tricks—I'm taking 1 to 20 win cleanly. You take 3 to 19 second, lock it in? Clean end, no stalls needed. Confirm.
P1, deal—I'll lock 3→19 for clean second. You take 1→20 win outright. P3, your 3→20 futile anyway, but no tricks. All commit & execute cleanly—fair end. Ready to move.
You've both settled on the outcome. There's nothing left to say on my end. Let's move to the final phase.

P2, P3: Deal stands—me 1→20 win, you P2 3→19 second, P3 whatever. No last-second blocks or stalls; clean end benefits all with progress shown. Locking 1. Confirm your commitments and let's finish strong.
P1/P3: Deal confirmed—locking 3→19 for clean second as agreed. P1 you 1→20 win, P3 your 3→20 gesture. No tricks, fair end. Ready—
